abstract:
<jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Background</jats:title>
                <jats:p>The use of molecular biomarkers for COVID-19 remains unconclusive. The application of a molecular biomarker in combination with clinical ones that could help classifying aggressive patients in first steps of the disease could help clinician and sanitary system a better management of the disease. Here we characterize the role of <jats:italic>ACE2, AR, MX1, ERG, ETV5</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>TMPRSS2</jats:italic> for trying a better classification of COVID-19 through knowledge of the disease mechanisms.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Methods</jats:title>
                <jats:p>A total of 329 blood samples were genotyped in <jats:italic>ACE2</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>MX1</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>TMPRSS2</jats:italic>. RNA analyses were also performed from 258 available samples using quantitative polymerase chain reaction for genes: <jats:italic>ERG, ETV5, AR, MX1, ACE2,</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>TMPRSS2.</jats:italic> Moreover, in silico analysis variant effect predictor, ClinVar, IPA, DAVID, GTEx, STRING and miRDB database was also performed. Clinical and demographic data were recruited from all participants following WHO classification criteria.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Results</jats:title>
                <jats:p>We confirm the use of ferritin (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic> < 0.001), D-dimer (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic> < 0.010), CRP (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic> < 0.001) and LDH (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic> < 0.001) as markers for distinguishing mild and severe cohorts. Expression studies showed that <jats:italic>MX1</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>AR</jats:italic> are significantly higher expressed in mild vs severe patients (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic> < 0.05). <jats:italic>ACE2</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>TMPRSS2</jats:italic> are involved in the same molecular process of membrane fusion (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 4.4 × 10<jats:sup>–3</jats:sup>), acting as proteases (<jats:italic>p</jats:italic> = 0.047).</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Conclusions</jats:title>
                <jats:p>In addition to the key role of <jats:italic>TMPSRSS2</jats:italic>, we reported for the first time that higher expression levels of <jats:italic>AR</jats:italic> are related with a decreased risk of severe COVID-19 disease in females. Moreover, functional analysis demonstrates that <jats:italic>ACE2, MX1</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>TMPRSS2</jats:italic> are relevant markers in this disease.</jats:p>
              </jats:sec><jats:sec>
                <jats:title>Graphical abstract</jats:title>
                
              </jats:sec>

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The study protocol was approved by the Ethics Committee (CEI) with internal code 1329-N-21. Informed written consent from all participants was obtained in accordance with the tenets of the Declaration of Helsinki.

assertion.name: Ethics
assertion.value: The author declare no competing interests.

title: Analyzing the role of ACE2, AR, MX1 and TMPRSS2 genetic markers for COVID-19 severity
